{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2016}} The '''Jade Helm 15 conspiracy theories''' were based on the Jade Helm 15 United States [[military exercise|military training exercise]] which took place in multiple U.S. states in the summer of 2015, starting on July 15 and ending on September 15. The announcements of these training exercises raised concerns and led to speculative interpretations that were characterized by ''[[The New York Times]]'' as "travers[ing] the outer edges of political paranoia".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/07/us/conspiracy-theories-over-jade-helm-get-some-traction-in-texas.html|title=Conspiracy Theories Over Jade Helm Training Exercise Get Some Traction in Texas|work=The New York Times|author=Manny Fernandez|date=May 6, 2015|accessdate=May 8, 2015}}</ref>
== Exercise details == The joint exercise in [[Military simulation|realistic military training (RMT)]]<!--It wasn't training in [[unconventional warfare]] as that is defined in the Wiki article--> known as Jade Helm 15<ref>The military has not defined "Jade Helm 15" for the public as of January 2016. The acronym JADE stands for "Joint Assistant for Deployment and Execution," "a knowledge-based mixed-initiative system that supports force deployment planning and management. JADE uses case-based and generative planning methods to support the development of large-scale, complex deployment plans in minimal time." [http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/398021.pdf Joint Assistant for Development and Execution (JADE)], Abstract, p. 1. [[Defense Technical Information Center]]. Retrieved January 8, 2016.</ref> was sponsored by the [[United States Special Operations Command]] (USSOCOM or SOCOM)<ref name="request">{{cite web |url=https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B3axduuybL0jdjZQUjhsSmJsZTA/edit |title=Request to Conduct Realistic Military Training (RMT) Jade Helm 15 |author=<!--no author named--> |date=<!--undated--> |publisher=[[United States Army Special Operations Command]] |access-date=January 8, 2016}}</ref> and involved the [[United States Army Special Operations Command]] (USASOC) and [[Joint Special Operations Command]] (JSOC) with other [[United States Armed Forces|U.S. Military]] units in multiple states, including Texas, Arizona, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, New Mexico, and Utah. Its stated purpose was "to improve the Special Operations Forces' capability as part of the National Security Strategy".<ref name="request"/> It was coordinated and led from [[Eglin Air Force Base]], an [[Air Force Materiel Command]] (AFMC) base in northwest Florida.<ref name="access">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/07/08/jade-helm-15-heavily-scrutinized-military-exercise-to-open-without-media-access/ |author=Lamothe, Dan |title=Jade Helm 15, heavily scrutinized military exercise, to open without media access |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=July 8, 2015 |access-date=January 8, 2016}}</ref>
Approximately 1,200 troops were engaged over the course of the exercise.<ref name="access"/> They were "mainly [[Special Forces (United States Army)|Army Green Berets]], but also a small group of [[United States Navy SEALs|Navy SEALS]] and Air Force special operations troops as well as conventional Army infantry",<ref name="cnn._Pent">{{Cite news | title = Pentagon claims it won't be taking over Texas | last = Starr | first = Barbara | publisher = CNN | date = May 4, 2015 | accessdate = May 6, 2015 | url = http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/04/politics/pentagon-texas-jade-helm-15-takeover/ }}</ref> although the initial request to state officials from USSOCOM listed elements of the [[United States Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command]] (MARSOC), Marine expeditionary units, the [[82nd Airborne Division]], and "interagency partners" as participants.<ref name="request"/> Troops engaging in the exercise assumed the roles of either occupying or resistance forces.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/16/us/in-texas-a-military-exercise-is-met-by-some-with-suspicion.html |title=As Jade Helm 15 Military Exercise Begins, Texans Keep Watch 'Just in Case' |last1=Fernandez |first1=Manny |date=July 15, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=January 8, 2016 |quote=Local officials who have been briefed on the exercise say it is modeled after the French resistance to Nazi occupation during World War II. It calls for some military personnel to play the role of the occupiers and for others to work undetected as part of the resistance.}}</ref> Most locations were in sparsely populated arid regions near small towns. Some participants wore civilian attire and drove civilian vehicles.<ref name=NYT71515>{{cite news|title=As Jade Helm 15 Military Exercise Begins, Texans Keep Watch 'Just in Case'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/16/us/in-texas-a-military-exercise-is-met-by-some-with-suspicion.html|accessdate=July 16, 2015|author=Manny Fernandez|work=The New York Times|date=July 15, 2015|quote= ... some Jade Helm 15 participants "may conduct suspicious activities" as part of their training and others "will be wearing civilian attire and driving civilian vehicles."}}</ref> Maps of the exercise included areas of the United States such as Colorado and California where no actual operations were planned.<ref name="wash_WhyO">{{Cite news |title = Why Operation Jade Helm 15 is freaking out the Internet — and why it shouldn't be |last = Lamothe | first = Dan| work =[[The Washington Post]]| date = March 31, 2015 |accessdate = May 1, 2015| url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/03/31/why-the-new-special-operations-exercise-freaking-out-the-internet-is-no-big-deal/}}</ref> The cities in Texas include [[Bastrop, Texas|Bastrop]], [[Smithville, Texas|Smithville]], [[Big Spring, Texas|Big Spring]], [[Caddo Lake]], [[Caldwell, Texas|Caldwell]], [[Christoval, Texas|Christoval]], [[College Station, Texas|College Station]], [[Dell City, Texas|Dell City]], [[Eldorado, Texas|Eldorado]], [[Goliad, Texas|Goliad]], [[Junction, Texas|Junction]], [[Leakey, Texas|Leakey]], [[Menard, Texas|Menard]], [[Mountain Home, Texas|Mountain Home]], [[San Angelo, Texas|San Angelo]], [[San Antonio]], and [[Victoria, Texas|Victoria]].<ref>{{Cite web |title = Covert warfare coming to Texas sparks some fears of federal takeover |last = Baddour| first = Dylan| work =[[Houston Chronicle]]| date = March 25, 2015 |accessdate = June 7, 2015| url = http://www.chron.com/news/article/Covert-warfare-comming-to-Texas-6157685.php}}</ref>
USSOCOM claimed that "the size and scope of Jade Helm sets this one apart" from previous training exercises,<ref name="soc._1503">{{Cite web| title = 150324-03 PRESS RELEASE: Exercise readies SOF for threats abroad| author = USASOC News Service|publisher = [[United States Army Special Operations Command]]| date = March 24, 2015| accessdate = May 1, 2015| url = http://www.soc.mil/UNS/Releases/2015/March/150324-03.html}}</ref> such as [[Marine Raider Regiment#Phase 4|Derna Bridge]] or [[United States Army Special Forces selection and training#UW CULEX (Robin Sage): Phase V (4 weeks)|Robin Sage]].<ref name="wash_WhyO"/> According to [[CNN]], Lt. Col. Mark Lastoria spoke at an information session for residents in Bastrop, Texas and said that the realistic military training helps soldiers adapt to unfamiliar terrain. In Bastrop, 60 soldiers took part, including the presence of two [[Humvee]] vehicles and a "water buffalo" water tank. Private land offered by residents would be used for the exercise, though he noted that they would not be paid for the land or receive a tax break of any kind.<ref name="kxan_1">{{Cite web | title = Gov. Abbott directs Texas Guard to monitor Jade Helm 15 operations | last = Beausoleil | first = Sophia | publisher = KXAN.com | date = April 27, 2015 | accessdate = May 6, 2015 | url = http://kxan.com/2015/04/27/bastrop-residents-question-jade-helm-15-operation/}}</ref> Lastoria also claimed that $150,000 in revenue would be brought to the area because of food, fuel, and shopping.
Journalists were not allowed to [[Embedded journalism|embed]] in the operation, but the [[Texas State Guard]] and the civilian group Counter Jade Helm monitored the exercise.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jahner, Kyle|title=Jade Helm 15: Controversial military exercise starts Wednesday|url=http://www.armytimes.com/story/military/2015/07/14/jade-helm-starts-army-special-operations-exercise/30144561/|newspaper=[[Army Times]]|date=July 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Civilians Begin Shadowing 'Jade Helm' War Exercise in Texas|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2015/07/15/us/ap-us-military-training-texas.html|type=[[Associated Press]]|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Chron-2015-07-13">{{cite news|author=Baddour, Dylan|title=Texans organize 'Operation Counter Jade Helm' to keep an eye on the federal troops|url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/texas/article/Texans-organize-Operation-Counter-Jade-Helm-to-6378017.php|newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]]|date=July 13, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Daily-Mail-2015-07-16">{{cite news|author=O'Connell, Oliver|title=Secretive military operation 'Jade Helm' gets underway across seven states - as conspiracy theorists who fear it signals imminent martial law flock to monitor 'war simulation' exercise|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3163212/MASSIVE-military-operation-Jade-Helm-gets-underway-seven-states-volunteers-flock-monitor-secretive-exercise-fearing-imminent-martial-law.html|type=[[Associated Press]]|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|date=July 16, 2015|location=London}}</ref>
== Conspiracy theories == [[File:Jade helm 15.jpeg|thumb|320px|U.S. Army Special Operations Command map,<ref>{{cite news|author=Wofford, Taylor|title=Jade Helm: The Conspiracy Theory That's Divided Texas Politicians|url=http://www.newsweek.com/jade-helm-conspiracy-theory-thats-divided-texas-politicians-328760|newspaper=[[Newsweek]]|date=May 5, 2015}}</ref><ref name="wash_WhyO"/> depicting the US military plans during the Jade Helm 15 exercise]] The conspiracy theories seem to emanate from the map shown here from the U.S. Army Special Operations Command which divides the region into four colors, with two "hostile" states, two "permissive" states, two states leaning one way or the other, and California divided.<ref>{{cite news|title=Operation Jade Helm 15: Military training exercise or martial law? Ask the Internet|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-ff-na-jade-helm-20150508-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=May 17, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150517165341/http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-ff-na-jade-helm-20150508-story.html|archivedate=May 17, 2015|date=May 8, 2015}}</ref> Jim Shea of the ''[[Hartford Courant]]''{{'}}s wrote that the conspiracy theories included: a "psychological operation aimed at getting people used to seeing military forces on the streets" so that they do not realize when an invasion actually takes place; an international operation aimed to seize people's guns; recently closed Walmarts used by the military to "stockpile supplies for Chinese troops who will be arriving to disarm Americans"; and a military plan to "round up political dissidents" and "remove key political figures" who may be against the imposition of [[martial law]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shea|first1=Jim|title=Thank You Texas and Good Luck with the Invasion|url=http://www.courant.com/features/too-shea/hc-shea-weakinreview-0517-20150517-column.html|work=Hartford Courant|accessdate=May 17, 2015}}</ref> Other theories have described Jade Helm 15 as a "secret plot" to impose martial law, confiscate firearms, invade Texas, and institute "total population control."<ref name=nytimestheories>{{cite news|last1=Fernadez|first1=Manny|title=In Texas, a Military Exercise Is Met by Some With Suspicion|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/16/us/in-texas-a-military-exercise-is-met-by-some-with-suspicion.html|accessdate=July 16, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=July 14, 2015}}</ref>
The conspiracy theories also included concern about the name of the exercise, with the "[[jade]]" possibly referring to [[China]],<ref>{{cite magazine|author=Davidson, Amy|title=Who Is Threatening Texas? – Unclear Dangers|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/05/18/unclear-dangers|magazine=[[The New Yorker]]|date=May 18, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Dale, Daniel|title=Texas invasion? U.S. army fights 'Jade Helm' conspiracy theories|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2015/05/06/texas-invasion-us-army-fights-jade-helm-conspiracy-theories.html|newspaper=[[Toronto Star Newspapers]]|date=May 6, 2015}}</ref> or possibly an acronym for [[artificial intelligence]] developed by the [[U.S. military]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Saal, Mark|title=Jade Helm: What if conspiracy theorists finally got it right?|url=http://www.standard.net/Standard-Deviations/2015/07/18/Jade-Helm-15-What-if-they-re-right.html|newspaper=[[Standard-Examiner]]|publisher=Ogden Publishing Corporation|date=July 18, 2015}}</ref> Conspiracy theorist and Texas radio host [[Alex Jones (radio host)|Alex Jones]] said that "helm" is an acronym for "Homeland Eradication of Local Militants".<ref name=nytimestheories/>
There was some tie-in between the Jade Helm 15 exercise and a resurgence of the [[FEMA camps conspiracy theory]] with the exercise raising fear that it was a dry run for forcing patriots into [[internment camp]]s.<ref name="Reinhard2015">{{cite web |last1=Reinhard |first1=Chelsea |title=County Denounces Conspiracy Theories, Approves Jade Helm 15 |url=https://sanangelolive.com/news/county/2015-05-07/county-denounces-conspiracy-theories-approves-jade-helm-15 |website=sanangelolive.com |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref> These fears were unfounded when the exercise was completed and no one was placed into a camp.<ref name="Smith2015">{{cite news |last1=Smith |first1=Morgan |title=In Bastrop, Jade Helm Begins With a Whimper |url=https://www.texastribune.org/2015/07/15/bastrop-jade-helm-begins/ |accessdate=6 June 2018 |publisher=Texas Tribune |date=15 July 2015}}</ref>
===Comet or asteroid impact=== Some conspiracy theorists have connected the Jade Helm 15 military exercise with an [[apocalypse]] caused by a [[comet]] or [[asteroid]] striking the Earth.<ref>{{cite news|author=Tamblyn, Thomas|title=Conspiracy Theorists Claim Massive 'Jade Helm' Military Exercise Is Preparation For The Apocalypse|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2015/06/08/conspiracy-theorists-claim-massive-jade-helm-military-exercise-is-preparation-for-the-apocalypse_n_7532874.html|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=June 8, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Express-2015-06-08">{{cite news|author=Austin, Jon|title=US military secretly preparing for asteroid that will wipe out mankind in September|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/weird/583002/US-military-secretly-preparing-asteroid-wipe-out-mankind-September-Jade-Helm|newspaper=[[Daily Express]]|date=June 8, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Dubuis, Anna|title=America 'preparing for asteroid impact with massive army training exercise to stop apocalypse riots'|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/weird-news/america-preparing-asteroid-impact-massive-5846883|newspaper=[[Daily Mirror]]|date=June 8, 2015}}</ref> The Jade Helm 15 military exercise had an ending date of September 15, 2015, which is the same month identified by some conspiracy theorists for the catastrophic impact of a comet or asteroid,<ref>{{cite news|title=Asteroid Impact Apocalypse 2015: Mass Anxiety As Conspiracy Theorists Predict Catastrophe|url=http://www.inquisitr.com/1813936/asteroid-impact-apocalypse-2015-mass-anxiety-as-conspiracy-theorists-predict-catastrophe/|publisher=The Inquisitr News|date=February 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Nelson, Sara C.|title=Asteroid Apocalypse Spells End Of The World In September 2015|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2015/06/08/asteroid-apocalypse-spells-end-world-september-2015_n_7533130.html|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=June 8, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Yahoo-2015-06-08">{{cite news|author=Wells, Andy|title=The World Is Going To End In September (Apparently)|url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/the-world-is-going-to-end-in-september--apparently-082010971.html#oE4A9RB|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=June 8, 2015}}</ref> based in part on a statement made May 13, 2014 by the French Foreign Minister [[Laurent Fabius]] that the world has "500 days to avoid climate chaos".<ref>{{cite news|author=Goodenough, Patrick|title=French Foreign Minister: 'We Have 500 Days to Avoid Climate Chaos'|url=http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/patrick-goodenough/french-foreign-minister-we-have-500-days-avoid-climate-chaos|publisher=[[cnsnews.com]]|date=May 13, 2014}}</ref> The conspiracy theorists claim that Jade Helm 15 is a dress rehearsal for the imposition of [[martial law]]<ref name="Express-2015-06-08"/><ref>{{cite news|title=2.5-Mile-Wide Comet Headed Toward Earth: Conspiracy Theorists Spread Doomsday Mass Hysteria|url=http://www.inquisitr.com/2054665/2-5-mile-wide-comet-headed-toward-earth-conspiracy-theorists-spread-doomsday-mass-hysteria/|publisher=The Inquisitr News|date=May 1, 2015}}</ref> which would be implemented in the event of a catastrophe of this level of severity. However, the [[NASA]] [[Near Earth Object Program]] publishes the [[Sentry Risk Table]], which is a list that identifies such threats, and the list does not include any object with a high [[Torino Scale]] number (a measure of the severity of the threat) for 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sentry Risk Table |url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/ |publisher=[[Near Earth Object Program|NASA – Near Earth Object Program]] |accessdate=June 12, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141231154154/http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/ |archivedate=December 31, 2014 |df= }}</ref> Also, a NASA spokesperson said, "NASA knows of no asteroid or comet currently on a collision course with Earth".<ref name="Yahoo-2015-06-08"/><ref name="Express-2015-06-08"/> But some conspiracy theorists claim that the object has been tracked for years,<ref>{{cite news|title=Confirmed-2.5 Mile Wide Comet Headed Toward Earth With Chilling, Hellish Mystery Sounds and Screams |url=http://www.disclose.tv/news/confirmed25_mile_wide_comet_headed_toward_earth_with_chilling_hellish_mystery_sounds_and_screams/117304 |publisher=Disclose.tv |date=April 29, 2015}}</ref> the object name is known but its published coordinates and orbit information are incorrect, and the threat is not publicly listed because of the thought that panic would ensue.<ref>{{cite news|author=Duclos, Susan|title=E.L.E. (Extinction Level Event) Coming? Asteroid Warning, Govt Preps Underground Bases & "Extinction Protocol"|url=http://allnewspipeline.com/ELE_Coming_Asteroid_Warning_Govt.php|publisher=All News Pipeline|date=January 4, 2015}}</ref> The apocalypse failed to happen on September 15, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|author=cosbourn|title=ISS Daily Summary Report – 09/15/15|url=https://blogs.nasa.gov/stationreport/2015/09/15/|publisher=NASA|date=September 15, 2015}}</ref>
== Reactions ==
The ''[[Austin American-Statesman]]'' newspaper noted that after plans and maps of the exercise were made public, there was an "explosion of outrage on social media after the release of the map, which labeled Texas, Utah and the southern tip of California as 'hostile.'"<ref name="stat_Texa">{{Cite web| title = Texas labeled as 'hostile' territory in Army's Jade Helm training| last = Walsh|first = Sean Collins| work = Austin American Statesman |date = April 28, 2015| accessdate = May 1, 2015| url = http://www.statesman.com/news/news/national/bastrop-critics-on-armys-jade-helm-training-come-a/nk454/}}</ref> There was also speculation that shuttered [[Walmart]] stores would be used for "[[Guerrilla warfare|guerrilla-warfare]] staging areas and [[Federal Emergency Management Agency|FEMA]] processing camps",<ref name="npr._Texa">{{Cite web| title = Texas Governor Deploys State Guard To Stave Off Obama Takeover| last = Goodwyn | first = Wade|publisher = NPR|author-link=Wade Goodwyn|date = May 2, 2015| accessdate = May 4, 2015| url = https://www.npr.org/blogs/itsallpolitics/2015/05/02/403865824/texas-governor-deploys-state-guard-to-stave-off-obama-takeover}}</ref> though this theory was debunked by the website [[Snopes]].<ref>Mikkelson, Barbara (April 23, 2015). [http://www.snopes.com/politics/conspiracy/walmartclosures.asp "Walmartyrs to the Cause"]. [[Snopes]].</ref>
A survey of registered Republicans by [[Public Policy Polling]] in May 2015,<ref>{{cite web|title=Poll Press release|url=http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/2015/PPP_Release_National_51315.pdf|publisher=Public Policy Polling|accessdate=May 14, 2015}}</ref> found that 32% thought that "the Government is trying to take over Texas", and that half of all [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] supporters are concerned with an imminent Texas invasion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Majority of likely GOP primary voters could believe Operation Jade Helm 15 is probably a federal invasion of Texas|url=http://www.salon.com/2015/05/14/majority_of_likely_gop_primary_voters_believe_operation_jade_helm_15_is_a_federal_invasion_of_texas/|work=Salon|accessdate=May 14, 2015}}</ref>
Greg Capers, sheriff of [[San Jacinto County, Texas|San Jacinto County]], published a letter in the ''[[Cleveland Advocate]]'' (of [[Cleveland, Texas]]), in response to numerous phone calls from citizens, in which he described "alternative news sources" that were spreading inaccurate information about the exercise, and encouraged citizens to "utilize legitimate mainstream news sources" for those interested in accurate information.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sheriff Capers issues letter to community regarding Operation Jade Helm|url=http://www.yourhoustonnews.com/cleveland/news/sheriff-capers-issues-letter-to-community-regarding-operation-jade-helm/article_e2c798c4-7d16-5f43-b2bd-61999b79acd6.html|publisher=Cleveland Advocate|accessdate=May 17, 2015}}</ref>
=== Politicians === On April 28, Texas Governor [[Greg Abbott]] ordered the [[Texas State Guard]] to monitor the operation. "During the training operation, it is important that Texans know [that] their safety, constitutional rights, private property rights and civil liberties will not be infringed."<ref name="stat_Texa" /><ref name="texa_Abbo">{{cite web|title=Abbott's Letter Elevates Jade Helm 15 Concerns|last=Svitek |first=Patrick|work=The Texas Tribune|date=April 30, 2015|accessdate=May 1, 2015|url=https://www.texastribune.org/2015/04/30/abbotts-letter-puts-jade-helm-national-stage/}}</ref>
On May 2, 2015, Texas senator [[Ted Cruz]] told the [[South Carolina Republican Party]]'s annual convention that he had "reached out to [[the Pentagon]] to inquire about this exercise."
<blockquote>We are assured [that] it is a military training exercise. I have no reason to doubt those assurances, but I understand the reason for concern and uncertainty, because when the federal government has not demonstrated itself to be trustworthy in this administration, the natural consequence is that many citizens don't trust what it is saying.<ref name="bloo_TedC">{{cite news|title=Ted Cruz Says He Has Asked the Pentagon for Answers on Jade Helm 15|last=Weigel |first=David|publisher=Bloomberg Politics|date=May 2, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2015-05-02/ted-cruz-says-he-has-asked-the-pentagon-for-answers-on-jade-helm-15}}</ref><ref name="bloo_Worr">{{cite news |title=Worried about Operation Jade Helm? Texas Republicans Hear You |last=Knowles |first=David |publisher=Bloomberg |date=May 6, 2015 |accessdate=May 6, 2015 |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2015-05-06/4-texas-republicans-sympathetic-over-jade-helm-15-fears}}</ref></blockquote>
[[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] [[Louie Gohmert]] said in a statement on May 5, 2015 that his "office has been inundated with calls referring to the Jade Helm 15 military exercise" with concerns that the U.S. Army is preparing for "modern-day martial law". He alluded to a notorious remark made by Barack Obama, who claimed that Pennsylvanians were "bitter" and "cling to guns or religion":<ref>https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950CE0D61E3CF932A2575AC0A96E9C8B63</ref> "I was rather appalled that the hostile areas amazingly have a Republican majority, 'cling to their guns and religion,' and believe in the sanctity of the United States Constitution". He asserted that "the map of the exercise needs to change, the names on the map need to change, and the tone of the exercise needs to be completely revamped so the federal government is not intentionally practicing war against its own states."<ref name="bloo_Worr" /><ref name="nati_Loui">{{cite web |title=Louie Gohmert Gets Why Some Texans Are Worried About a Military Takeover |last=Berman |first=Matt |work=National Journal |date=May 5, 2015 |accessdate=May 6, 2015 |url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/congress/louie-gohmert-gets-why-some-texans-are-worried-about-a-military-takeover-20150505 }}</ref><ref name="gohm_Gohm">{{cite web |title=Gohmert Statement on Jade Helm Exercises : U.S. Congressman Louie Gohmert |last=Gohmert |first=Louie |publisher=gohmert.house.gov |date=May 5, 2015 |accessdate=May 6, 2015 |url=http://gohmert.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398216}}</ref>
In a November 2015 ''[[GQ]]'' interview, President Obama described Jade Helm as "his favorite conspiracy theory".<ref>{{cite news|work=San Francisco Chronicle|url=http://www.sfgate.com/national/article/Obama-picks-Jade-Helm-as-his-favorite-6644618.php|title=Obama picks 'Jade Helm' as his favorite conspiracy theory about his presidency|author=Matt Levin|date=November 19, 2015}}</ref>
=== Media === All News Pipeline<ref>http://allnewspipeline.com/Jade_Helm_2015.php</ref> broke Jade Helm to the world on March 13, 2015, 5 days before conspiracy theorist and radio host [[Alex Jones (radio host)|Alex Jones]], who began spreading the conspiracy theory on March 19, 2015, by saying on his radio program and on his website that the federal government was preparing to invade Texas.<ref name=globe>{{cite news |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2015/05/25/divided-america-theories-military-takeover-texas-find-legitimacy-political-mainstream/KSScgClOewjIXXisqkF5IM/story.html |title=Suspicion of US government reaches a new level in Texas |first=Matt |last=Viser |date=May 26, 2015 |accessdate=May 26, 2015 |newspaper=Boston Globe}}</ref> "They're going to practice breaking into things and stuff. This is going to be hellish," Jones said. "Now this is just a cover for deploying the military on the streets ... This is an invasion ... in preparation for the financial collapse and maybe even Obama not leaving office."<ref name=globe />
In reaction to the sentiment that the military exercises might in fact be movement against American citizens, ''[[Dallas Morning News]]'' columnist Jacquielynn Floyd wrote a column titled, "Abbott should counter, not cater to, Texans' crazy Jade Helm fears," noting that Abbott's "response to this nut-studded fruitcake of fear was unfortunate."<ref name="dall_Floy">{{cite web|title=Floyd: Abbott should counter, not cater to, Texans' crazy Jade Helm fears|last=Floyd |first=Jacquielynn|work=Dallas Morning News |date=April 30, 2015|accessdate=May 1, 2015|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/columnists/jacquielynn-floyd/20150430-floyd-to-ease-takeover-fears-abbott-needs-to-call-crazy-what-it-is.ece}}</ref> On April 29, [[White House Press Secretary]] [[Josh Earnest]] addressed the concerns of critics in the regular press briefing, saying, "I have no idea what he's thinking," regarding Abbott's letter to the Texas Guard. "In no way will the constitutional rights or civil liberties of any American citizen be infringed upon while this exercise is being conducted."<ref name="bloo_Whoa">{{cite news|title=Whoa, If True: 'Operation Jade Helm 15' Lays Groundwork for Martial Law|last=Knowles |first=David|publisher=[[Bloomberg Politics]]|date=April 29, 2015|accessdate=May 1, 2015|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2015-04-29/whoa-if-true-operation-jade-helm-15-lays-groundwork-for-martial-law}}</ref><ref name="talk_Whit">{{cite web|title=White House On A Possible Military Takeover Of Texas: Um, No|last=Thompson" |first=Catherine|work=Talking Points Memo|date=April 30, 2015|accessdate=May 1, 2015 |url=http://talkingpointsmemo.com/livewire/white-house-texas-military-takeover}}</ref>
Comedian [[Jon Stewart]] addressed the debate around the exercises in a segment on ''[[The Daily Show]]'' on May 4 called "Fear and Absent Danger", noting that previous military exercises while Republican [[Rick Perry]] was governor did not raise similar concerns.<ref name="wash_Watc">{{cite news |title=Watch Jon Stewart rip reaction to Jade Helm 15, the military exercise spawning conspiracy theories |last=Lamothe |first=Dan |work=The Washington Post |date=May 5, 2015 |accessdate=May 6, 2015 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/05/05/watch-jon-stewart-rip-reaction-to-jade-helm-15-the-military-exercise-spawning-conspiracy-theories/}}</ref><ref name="aust_'Dai">{{cite web |title='Daily Show' makes a mockery of 'Lone Star lunatics' and Jade Helm 15 |work=All Ablog Austin |date=May 5, 2015 |accessdate=May 6, 2015 |url=http://austin.blog.statesman.com/2015/05/05/daily-show-makes-a-manhattan-mockery-of-lone-star-lunatics-over-jade-helm-15/}}</ref>
=== Polls === A survey by [[Public Policy Polling]] between May 7 and May 10, 2015, found that 32% of 685 Republican primary voters believed "the government is trying to take over Texas", 40% believed "the government is not trying to take over Texas" and 28% were "unsure".<ref>{{cite web|title=Many GOP voters buy into 'Jade Helm' conspiracy theory|url=http://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow-show/many-gop-voters-buy-jade-helm-conspiracy-theory|accessdate=September 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>[https://www.publicpolicypolling.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/PPP_Release_National_51315.pdf "Walker Leads Tightly Clustered GOP Field, Clinton Up Big Nationally", by Public Policy Polling]</ref>
== Russian disinformation == [[Clint Watts]], and two others in the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] began to notice [[Russia]]n disinformation campaigns starting in April 2014.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://wtop.com/j-j-green-national/2017/09/anatomy-russian-attack-first-signs/slide/1/|title=Anatomy of a Russian attack: First signs of the Kremlin's attempt to influence the 2016 election|last=Green|first=J. J.|date=2017-09-18|work=WTOP|access-date=2018-05-03|language=en-US}}</ref> Watts said that Russian-driven efforts to spread misinformation were involved with Jade Helm 15.<ref name=":0" /> In 2017, [[Facebook]] shut down a page called "Heart of Texas" which was found to be associated with a Russian company promoting disinformation, including promoting the Jade Helm conspiracy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://extranewsfeed.com/how-russia-created-the-most-popular-texas-secession-page-on-facebook-fd4dfd05ee5c|title=How Russia Created the Most Popular Texas Secession Page on Facebook|last=Michel|first=Casey|date=2017-09-07|work=Extra Newsfeed|access-date=2018-05-03}}</ref>
On May 3, 2018, ''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' reported that [[Michael Hayden (general)|Michael Hayden]], a former director of the CIA and NSA said that the "hysteria" surrounding the training exercise "was fueled by Russians wanting to dominate 'the information space.'"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.texastribune.org/2018/05/03/hysteria-over-jade-helm-exercise-texas-was-fueled-russians-former-cia-/|title=Hysteria over Jade Helm exercise in Texas was fueled by Russians, former CIA director says|last=Pollock|first=Cassandra|date=2018-05-03|work=The Texas Tribune|access-date=2018-05-03|last2=Samuels|first2=Alex|language=en}}</ref> Hayden said that [[Web brigades|Russian bots]] were used to spread misinformation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/politics/2018/05/03/former-cia-director-says-russians-spread-misinformation-jade-helm|title=Russians spread misinformation on Jade Helm military exercise in Texas, former CIA director says|last=Barragan|first=James|date=2018-05-03|work=Dallas News|access-date=2018-05-03|language=en}}</ref>

'''Jiang Gongfu''' ({{zh|姜公輔}}, [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] : ''Khương Công Phụ'' ; 731 – 805) was an official of the [[History of China|Chinese]] [[Tang Dynasty]] who served as a [[chancellor of Tang Dynasty|chancellor]] during the reign of [[Emperor Dezong of Tang|Emperor Dezong]]. __TOC__
==Biography== It is not known when Jiang Gongfu was born, but it is known that his family was from Ai Prefecture (愛州, in modern [[Thanh Hóa Province]], [[Vietnam]]),<ref>''[[New Book of Tang]]'', [http://www.sidneyluo.net/a/a17/152.htm vol. 152].</ref> although the family claimed to be originally from [[Tianshui]]. Jiang Gongfu's grandfather Jiang Shenyi (姜神翊) served as a prefectural prefect, but his father Jiang Ting (姜挺) was not listed with any official titles. He had at least one younger brother, Jiang Fu (姜復).<ref>''New Book of Tang'', vol. 73.{{cite web|url=http://www.sidneyluo.net/a/a17/073.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-04-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202171923/http://sidneyluo.net/a/a17/073.htm |archivedate=2009-02-02 |df= }} [http://www.sidneyluo.net/a/a17/table/form71.htm]</ref>
After Jiang Gongfu passed the [[imperial examination]]s he was made ''Xiaoshulang'' (校書郎), an editor at the [[Palace Library]]. After he passed a special examination on policy proposals, he was made ''Zuo Shiyi'' (左拾遺), an advisor at the examination bureau of government (門下省, ''Menxia Sheng''), and he was also made an imperial scholar at Hanlin Pavilion (翰林館). After more than a year, when he was to be given a different office, he submitted a petition, citing the poverty of his household and the agedness of his mother, requesting to be also made the census officer under the mayor of Jingzhao Municipality (京兆, i.e., the region of the capital [[Chang'an]]), because the census officer, while a low-level position, had a high salary, and his petition was granted. He was said to be capable and sensible, and whenever he met [[Emperor Dezong of Tang|Emperor Dezong]] to make suggestions, Emperor Dezong often followed his suggestions.<ref name=BT138>''[[Old Book of Tang]]'', [http://www.sidneyluo.net/a/a16/138.htm vol. 138] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080621210544/http://www.sidneyluo.net/a/a16/138.htm |date=2008-06-21 }}.</ref>
In 783, with Emperor Dezong waging wars against several warlords in the east, the soldiers from Jingyuan Circuit (涇原, headquartered in modern [[Pingliang]], [[Gansu]]), were at Chang'an to await deployment to the east. They were angered that they were not given rewards that they felt they deserved, and they mutinied. Emperor Dezong sent his son Li Yi (李誼) the Prince of Pu<ref>Li Yi was actually Emperor Dezong's nephew — the son of Emperor Dezong's brother Li Miao (李邈), but was adopted by Emperor Dezong at the directions of Emperor Dezong. See ''Old Book of Tang'', [http://www.sidneyluo.net/a/a16/150.htm vol. 150] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080621210610/http://www.sidneyluo.net/a/a16/150.htm |date=2008-06-21 }} and ''[[Zizhi Tongjian]]'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷233|vol. 233]].</ref> and Jiang to try to calm the soldiers, but the soldiers merely got angrier, and Emperor Dezong, in panic, decided to flee Chang'an. As he was ready to do so, Jiang tried to warn him about the dangers of leaving the senior general [[Zhu Ci]] in the city – as Emperor Dezong had removed Zhu Ci from his command in 782 due to his brother [[Zhu Tao]]'s rebelling against imperial authority<ref>''Zizhi Tongjian'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷227|vol. 227]].</ref> – and had served as the military governor (''[[Jiedushi]]'') of Jingyuan Circuit before, and therefore might receive the Jingyuan soldiers' support. He suggested to Emperor Dezong that either he should kill Zhu Ci before leaving or ask Zhu to accompany him. Emperor Dezong, in panic, could not carry out either action, and left Zhu in the city. Emperor Dezong fled to Fengtian (奉天, in modern [[Xianyang]], [[Shaanxi]]), and Jiang followed him there.<ref name=ZZTJ228>''Zizhi Tongjian'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷228|vol. 228]].</ref>
Emperor Dezong issued emergency edicts seeking aid from the nearby circuits. Meanwhile, the Jingyuan soldiers did as Jiang predicted and supported Zhu as their leader. Zhu initially claimed that he was merely calming the situation at Chang'an and was ready to welcome Emperor Dezong back to Chang'an, but soon there were rumors that Zhu was planning to claim imperial title himself and attack Emperor Dezong at Fengtian. In light of this, some officials who had fled to Fengtian suggested that Fengtian's defenses be shored up, but the [[chancellor of Tang Dynasty|chancellor]] [[Lu Qi (Tang dynasty)|Lu Qi]], misjudging the situation, argued to Emperor Dezong that Zhu would surely remain faithful to Tang and advocated taking no precautions at all and stopping the incoming aid troops. It was only at Jiang's advice Emperor Dezong continued to receive the aid troops into Fengtian. At suggestion of Lu and Bai Zhizhen (白志貞) the commander of the imperial guards, Emperor Dezong sent his granduncle Wu Xu (吳漵) to Chang'an to communicate with Zhu. Zhu initially welcomed Wu as an honored imperial emissary, but soon put Wu to death. He declared himself emperor of a new state of Qin. He put Fengtian under siege, and during the siege, Emperor Dezong made Jiang ''Jianyi Daifu'' (諫議大夫), a high-level advisor at the examination bureau, and gave him the designation ''Tong Zhongshu Menxia Pingzhangshi'' (同中書門下平章事), making him a chancellor ''de facto''.<ref name=ZZTJ228/>
==During chancellorship== In 784, because the general [[Li Huaiguang]] also rebelled, Emperor Dezong fled further to Liang Prefecture (梁州, in modern [[Hanzhong]], [[Shaanxi]]), and Jiang Gongfu accompanied him. On the way to Liang Prefecture, Emperor Dezong's oldest daughter Princess Tang'an died at Chenggu (城固, in modern Hanzhong). After Emperor Dezong reached Liang Prefecture, he wanted to build a [[pagoda]] for Princess Tang'an and bury her with great wealth.<ref name=ZZTJ230>''Zizhi Tongjian'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷230|vol. 230]].</ref> Jiang submitted a petition stating:<ref name=BT138/>
{{quote|Soon, the capital will be recaptured, and the princess will be able to be reburied properly. We are now on the road, and we need to be frugal and use the money on the soldiers.}}
Emperor Dezong became angry and wanted to remove Jiang. Despite the intercession of Emperor Dezong's trusted advisor [[Lu Zhi (Tang Dynasty)|Lu Zhi]], Emperor Dezong soon removed Jiang and made him a member of the staff of his [[crown prince]] [[Emperor Shunzong of Tang|Li Song]].<ref name=ZZTJ230/>
==After chancellorship== Jiang Gongfu's mother soon died, and he left governmental service to observe a period of mourning for her. After the period of mourning, he was returned to Li Song's staff, but went a long time without being promoted.<ref name=BT138/> By 792, Lu Zhi was a chancellor. Because he and Lu Zhi were colleagues while they were imperial scholars, Jiang met Lu to request his help. Lu secretly responded:<ref name=ZZTJ234>''Zizhi Tongjian'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷234|vol. 234]].</ref>
{{quote|I had heard that Chancellor Dou [(i.e., [[Dou Can]], who had recently been removed and exiled by Emperor Dezong)] had recommended you a number of times. The Emperor refused, and had a number of angry words about you.}}
In fear, Jiang offered to resign and asked to become a [[Taoist]] [[monk]]. When Emperor Dezong inquired as to the reason and found out that he was fearful, he did not dare to state that Lu had told him this information, and instead claimed that Dou told him the information. Angry that his words had been leaked, Emperor Dezong demoted Jiang to be the secretary general of Quan Prefecture (泉州, in modern [[Quanzhou]], [[Fujian]]), and sent imperial [[Eunuch (court official)|eunuch]] messengers to Dou, in exile, to rebuke him. After Emperor Dezong died in 805 and was succeeded by Li Song (as Emperor Shunzong), Jiang was slightly promoted, to be the prefect of Ji Prefecture (吉州, in modern [[Ji'an]], [[Jiangxi]]). He soon died, and was posthumously honored by Emperor Shunzong's son and successor [[Emperor Xianzong of Tang|Emperor Xianzong]] (to whom Emperor Shunzong, then seriously ill, passed the throne to in 805 as well).<ref name=BT138/><ref>''Zizhi Tongjian'', [[:zh:s:資治通鑑/卷236|vol. 236]].</ref>

[[File:Prof. Joe Friggieri portrait.jpg|thumb|Joe Friggieri]] '''Prof. Joe Friggieri''' (born 1946) is Professor of Philosophy and a member of the Senate at the [[University of Malta]], poet, playwright and theatre director.<ref>[http://www.um.edu.mt/theology/philosophy/staff/jfriggieri "Department of Philosophy, Faculty of Arts"]</ref>
== Biography == Friggieri was the first professor of philosophy on the University of Malta faculty not to be a Catholic priest and succeeded [[Peter Serracino Inglott]] in 1996 upon the latter's retirement. He holds doctorates from the University of Milan (Cattolica) and [[The University of Oxford]]. Friggieri has been guest research scholar and lecturer at the Universities of Venice, Amsterdam, St Andrews, Augsburg and Genova.
Friggieri's publications include three volumes of poetry, three collections of short stories, a number of plays, as well as two volumes entitled ''In-Nisga tal-Hsieb'', the first history of philosophy publications in Maltese. He has won several literary awards, including the National Literary Prize three times (1993, 1999 and 2003). One of his most popular works is ''L-Istejjer tar-Ronnie'', published in 1994 by Klabb Kotba Maltin, which caricatures father of four ir-Ronnie, a Maltese middle-aged mechanic, in a series of short stories. The original publication was so popular that it was eventually turned into a teleserial.<ref>Stagno, Guze. [http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20080308/books/zero-the-hero.199532 "Zero the Hero"], ''[[The Times of Malta]]''</ref>
In 2004 Friggieri unsuccessfully contested Malta's first elections for the European Parliament on behalf of the governing Nationalist Party, garnering a total of 5457 votes on first count.<ref>[http://gov.mt/en/Government/Government%20of%20Malta/Election%20Results/European%20Parliament%20Elections%20-%202004/Pages/European%20Parliament%20Elections_2004.aspx "Department of Information"]</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} Very Rev '''John McIntyre''' [[Commander of the Royal Victorian Order|CVO]], [[Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh|FRSE]] (20 May 1916 – 15 December 2005) was a Scottish minister and theologian. He was [[Moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland]] 1982/83 and Chaplain to the Queen in Scotland from 1990 to 1996.
==Biography== McIntyre was born in [[Glasgow]] on 20 May 1916 into a working-class family;<ref name="soteriological269">Eamonn Mulcahy, ''The Cause of Our Salvation: Soteriological Causality according to some Modern British Theologians, 1988–98'' (Tesi Gregoriana Serie Teologia 140, Rome: Editrice Pontificia Università Gregoriana, 2007), p. 269.</ref> he was the son of a carpenter.<ref name="New College Bulletin">''New College Bulletin''</ref> He was educated at [[Bathgate Academy]] and the [[University of Edinburgh]] ([[Master of Arts (Scotland)|MA]] in Mental Philosophy [[First Class Honours|First-class honours]] 1938,<ref name="soteriological269"/> BD with Distinction).
He was ordained as a minister in the [[Church of Scotland]] in 1941 and worked in [[Glen Orchy]] and [[Inishail]] as [[Locum|''locum tenens'']] (1941–43) and in [[Fenwick, East Ayrshire|Fenwick]] as minister (1943–45).
In 1946 he was appointed Hunter Baillie Professor of Theology at [[St. Andrew's College, Sydney]]. He remained at the college until 1956, having been appointed Principal in 1950. He was elected Honorary Fellow in 1990. He obtained his DPhil in 1953.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1506037/Very-Rev-Prof-John-McIntyre.html ''Telegraph.co.uk'']</ref> In 1956 he was appointed [[Divinity (academic discipline)|Professor of Divinity]] in the [[University of Edinburgh]], having declined the offer of a position at [[Union Theological Seminary in the City of New York]].<ref name="New College Bulletin"/> He held the chair until 1986. He was in addition Principal of [[New College, Edinburgh|New College]]<ref name="scottish-places1">[http://www.scottish-places.info/people/famousfirst2935.html ''Gazetteer for Scotland'']</ref> and Dean of the Faculty of Divinity (1968–74) and acting Principal and Vice-Chancellor of the university (1973–74 and again in 1979). He was first senior warden of [[Pollock Halls of Residence]], where the refectory is now named in his honour.
In 1971 he was interim minister of the [[St. Giles' Cathedral|High Kirk of Edinburgh]].<ref name="timesonline1">[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article783381.ece?print=yes&randnum=1151003209000 ''The Times'']</ref> He was [[Dean of the Thistle|Dean of the Most Ancient and Most Noble Order of the Thistle]] from 1974 until 1989, [[Ecclesiastical Household|Extra Chaplain to the Queen in Scotland]] 1974–75,<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=46421 |date=3 December 1974 |page=12169}}</ref> [[Ecclesiastical Household|Chaplain]] 1975–86,<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=46572 |date=13 May 1975 |page=6195}}</ref> and [[Ecclesiastical Household|Extra Chaplain]] again 1986–2005. He was appointed [[Royal Victorian Order|Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]] by [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|HM The Queen]] in 1985.<ref>''Who Was Who?'' (2007), s.v. 'McIntyre, John'</ref>
In 1982 he succeeded Very Rev [[Andrew Beveridge Doig]] as the [[Moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland]]. From 1983 until 1987 he was convenor of the Church of Scotland Board of Education.<ref name="timesonline1"/>
In 1986 he was honoured with a ''[[Festschrift]]'', ''Religious imagination'', ed. James P. Mackey (Edinburgh University Press, 1986). Having taken the substantive degree of [[Doctor of Letters]] at [[University of Edinburgh|Edinburgh]], he was awarded honorary doctorates by the [[University of Edinburgh]] ([[Honorary degree|Doctor ''honoris causa'']]), [[University of Glasgow]] ([[Doctor of Divinity]]), and the [[College of Wooster]] ([[Doctor of Humane Letters]]).<ref name="timesonline1"/><ref>[http://www.ma.hw.ac.uk/RSE/fellowship/obits/obits_alpha/mcintyre_j.pdf ''Royal Society of Edinburgh obituary'']</ref> He was elected [[Royal Society of Edinburgh|Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] in 1977. He was a Member of Council 1979–86 and Vice-President 1983–86.
He retired in 1996 and died at [[The Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh]] on 15 December 2005.<ref name="scottish-places1"/>
==Publications==
*''The shape of christology: studies in the doctrine of the person of Christ'' (2nd edn, Edinburgh: T&T Clark, 1998; 1st edn, London: SCM, 1966) *''The shape of pneumatology: studies in the doctrine of the Holy Spirit'' (Edinburgh: T&T Clark, 1997) *''The shape of soteriology: studies in the doctrine of the death of Christ'' (T&T Clark, 1992) *''Faith theology, and imagination'' (Edinburgh: Handsel Press, 1987) *''Prophet of penitence: our contemporary ancestor'' (Edinburgh: Saint Andrew Press, 1972) *''The availability of Christ'' (Edinburgh: Scottish Church Society, 1962) *''On the love of God'' (London: Collins, 1962) *''The Christian doctrine of history'' (Edinburgh: Oliver and Boyd, 1957) *''St. Anselm and his critics: a re-interpretation of the Cur Deus homo'' (Edinburgh: Oliver and Boyd, 1954)
:''The Shape of Soteriology'' was recently studied in Eamonn Mulcahy, ''The Cause of Our Salvation: Soteriological Causality according to some Modern British Theologians, 1988–98'' (Tesi Gregoriana Serie Teologia 140, Rome: Editrice Pontificia Università Gregoriana, 2007), alongside [[Colin Gunton]], ''The Actuality of Atonement: a Study of Metaphor, Rationality and the Christian Tradition '' (Edinburgh: T&T Clark, 1988), [[Vernon White (theologian)|Vernon White]], ''Atonement and Incarnation: an essay in Universalism and Particularity'' (Cambridge University Press, 1991), and [[Paul Fiddes]], ''Past Event and Present Salvation: the Christian Idea of Atonement'' (London: Darton, Longman, & Todd, 1989).

'''Josef Simon''' (1 August 1930 – 28 March 2016) was a contemporary German philosopher and professor of the University of Bonn, born in [[Hupperath]]. He wrote extensively on [[metaphysics]], [[epistemology]], the philosophy of [[German idealism]] and various philosophers, mainly [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]], [[Hamann]] and [[Nietzsche]]. Perhaps Simon's most influential work has been in the [[philosophy of language]]. His main work, ''Philosophie des Zeichens'',<ref>{{cite book |title=Zur Philosophie des Zeichens |last=Borsche |first=Tilman |author2=Werner Stegmaier |year=1992 |publisher=[[Walter de Gruyter]] |isbn=978-3-11-013638-8 }}</ref> has been influenced by, among others, Kant, [[Hegel]], [[Charles Sanders Peirce|Peirce]] and [[Wittgenstein]], Hamann, [[Wilhelm von Humboldt|Humboldt]] or Nietzsche.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lebenswege.faz.net/traueranzeige/josef-simon/45567126|title=Josef Simon: Traueranzeige|date=30 March 2016|publisher=lebenswege.faz.net}}</ref>
He died in [[Bonn]].
==Selected publications==
''Das Problem der Sprache bei Hegel''. Kohlhammer-Verlag, Stuttgart 1966.
''Sprache und Raum. Philosophische Untersuchungen zum Verhältnis zwischen Wahrheit und Bestimmtheit von Sätzen.'' Verlag Walter de Gruyter, Berlin 1969.
''Sprachphilosophische Aspekte der Kategorienlehre''. Heiderhoff Verlag, Frankfurt/Main 1971
''Philosophie und linguistische Theorie''. Verlag Walter de Gruyter, Berlin/New York 1971.
''Wahrheit als Freiheit. Zur Entwicklung der Wahrheitsfrage in der neueren Philosophie''. Verlag Walter de Gruyter, Berlin/New York 1978.
''Sprachphilosophie'', Karl Alber Verlag, Freiburg/München 1981.
''Philosophie des Zeichens''. Verlag Walter de Gruyter, Berlin/New York 1989. English translation: ''Philosophy of the Sign''. State University of New York Press, 1995. Spanish translation: ''Filosofia del signo''. Gredos, Madrid 1998.
''Kant. Die fremde Vernunft und die Sprache der Philosophie''. Verlag Walter de Gruyter, Berlin/New York 2003.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Simon, Josef}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:German philosophers]] [[Category:German male writers]] [[Category:Philosophers of language]]
{{Germany-philosopher-stub}}

{{Multiple issues| {{disputed|date=August 2017}} {{refimprove|date=August 2017}} }} {{for|the social group of [[Himachal Pradesh]]|Kanaura}} {{distinguish|Kinara}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} [[File:Kinnon Wat Phra Kaew 02.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Statue of a ''kinnara'' in [[Wat Phra Kaew]], [[Bangkok]] ([[Thailand]]).]]
:''For the social group or caste amongst the Sinhalese of Sri Lanka, see [[Kinnaraya]]''
In [[Hindu mythology]], a '''kinnara''' is a [[paradigm]]atic lover, a celestial musician, [[Centaur|half-human and half-horse]] (India). In South-east Asia, two of the most beloved mythological characters are the benevolent half-human, half-bird creatures known as the Kinnara and Kinnari, which are believed to come from the Himalayas and often watch over the well-being of humans in times of trouble or danger. Their character is clarified in the Adi parva of the [[Mahabharata]], where they say:
:We are everlasting lover and beloved. We never separate. We are eternally husband and wife; never do we become mother and father. No offspring is seen in our lap. We are lover and beloved ever-embracing. In between us we do not permit any third creature demanding affection. Our life is a life of perpetual pleasure.<ref> {{cite book |author = Ghosh, Subodh |title = Love stories from the Mahabharata, transl. Pradip Bhattacharya |location = New Delhi | year = 2005 |publisher =Indialog }} p. 71</ref> They are also featured in a number of Buddhist texts, including the [[Lotus Sutra]]. An ancient Indian string instrument is known as the Kinnari [[Veena]].
In [[Southeast Asian]] mythology, '''Kinnaris''', the female counterpart of Kinnaras, are depicted as half-bird, half-woman creatures. One of the many creatures that inhabit the mythical [[Himavanta]], Kinnaris have the head, torso, and arms of a woman and the wings, tail and feet of a swan. They are renowned for their dance, song and poetry, and are a traditional symbol of feminine beauty, grace and accomplishment.
[[Edward H. Schafer]] notes that in East Asian religious art the Kinnara is often confused with the [[Kalaviṅka]], which is also a half-human half-bird hybrid mythical creature, but that the two are actually distinct and unrelated.<ref>{{Cite book | last=Schafer | first=Edward H. | authorlink=Edward H. Schafer | title=The Golden Peaches of Samarkand: A Study of Tʻang Exotics | publisher=University of California Press | year=1963 | page=103 }}</ref>
==Burma== [[File:Shan peacock dance.jpg|thumb|[[Shan people|Shan]] kinnara and kinnari dance]] In Burma (Myanmar), kinnara are called keinnaya or kinnaya ({{my|ကိန္နရာ}} {{IPA-my|kèɪɴnəjà|}}). Female kinnara are called keinnayi or kinnayi ({{my|ကိန္နရီ}} {{IPA-my|kèɪɴnəjì|}}). In [[Shan language|Shan]], they are {{my|ၵိင်ႇၼရႃႇ}} ({{IPA-shn|kìŋ nǎ ràː}}) and {{my|ၵိင်ႇၼရီႇ}} ({{IPA-shn|kìŋ nǎ rì}}) respectively. [[Buddhism in Burma|Burmese Buddhists]] believe that out of the 136 past animal lives of Buddha, four were kinnara. The kinnari is also one of the 108 symbols on the footprint of Buddha. [[File:Flag of Kayah State.svg|thumb|right|The flag of [[Kayah State]] (Karenni State) includes a depiction of the kinnara.]] In Burmese art, kinnari are depicted with covered breasts. The [[Myanmar Academy Awards]] statue for Academy Award winners is of a kinnari.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mmtimes.com/2010/feature/509/academy02.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100925180148/http://mmtimes.com/2010/feature/509/academy02.html |archivedate=25 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The kinnara and kinnari couple is considered the symbol of the [[Karenni]] people.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.myanmar.gov.mm/myanmartimes/no68/myanmartimes4-68/Timeouts/6.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070822213342/http://www.myanmar.gov.mm/myanmartimes/no68/myanmartimes4-68/Timeouts/6.htm |archivedate=22 August 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Cambodia==
In [[Cambodia]], the kinnaras are known in the [[Khmer language]] as '''kenar''' ({{lang|km|កិន្នរ}}, {{lang|km|កិន្នរា}}; {{IPA-km|keˈnɑː|IPA}} or ''{{IPA-km|ken nɑ ˈraː|IPA}}''). The female counterpart, the kinnari ({{lang|km|កិន្នរី}}; {{IPA-km|ken nɑ ˈrəj|IPA}}), are depicted in Cambodian art and literature more often than the male counterparts. They are commonly seen carved into support figurines for the columns of [[Khmer architecture|post-Angkorian architecture]]. Kinnari are considered symbols of beauty and are skilled dancers.<ref>Headley, Robert K. (1997). Modern Cambodian-English Dictionary, Dunwoody Press</ref> The kinnari is a character archetype in the repertoire of the [[Royal Ballet of Cambodia]], appearing as mischievous groups that have a strong allurement. A classical dance titled ''robam kinar'' depicts kinnaris playing in a lotus pond.
==India== In the Sanskrit language, the name Kinnara contains a question mark ([[Sanskrit]] : किन्नर?) i.e. is this man?. In Hindu mythology, Kinnara is described as half man, half-horse, and half-bird. The Vishnudharmottara describes Kinnara as half-man and half-horse, but the correct nature of Kinnara as Buddhists understood is half-man and half-bird. The figure of Yaksha with a horse head illustrated in Bodh Gaya sculptures in however a Kinnari as the Jataka illustrating it treats her as a demi-god. According to the Jatakas, Kinnaras are fairies and are shown as going in pairs noted for mutual love and devotion. In the Chanda Kinnara Jataka the devotion of the Kinnarai to her wounded Kinnara husband brings Indra on the scene to cure him from the wound. The Kinnaras are noted for their long life.<ref name=":1">{{cite web |title=Mythical Animals in Indian Art |url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=dMI4rZuRs1MC&pg=PA14&dq=Kinnaras&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KFoqVarqFdG0uATgx4DwAg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Kinnaras&f=false#Directive |year=1985 |publisher=Abhinav Publications }}</ref>
The Jatakas describe the Kinnaras as innocent and harmless, hop like birds, are fond of music and song, and with the female beating a drum and male playing on lute. Such harmless creatures are described in Jataka No.481 as being caught, put into cages, and thus presented to kings for their delight. In Jataka No.504, we have the autobiography of a Kinnara who describes the Kinnara class as human-like the wild things deem us; huntsmen call us goblins still. The Kinnaras can sing, play the flute and dance with soft movements of the body. Kalidasa in his Kumara Sambhava describes them as dwelling in the Himalayas. Kinnaras lived also over the hills of Pandaraka, Trikutaka, Mallangiri, Candapabbata, and Gandhamandana (Jataka No. 485). They were tender-hearted and Jataka No. 540 refers to the story of the Kinnaras nursing a human baby whose parents have gone away to the woods. Yet, we find that they were looked upon as queer animals and were hunted, captured and presented to the kings as entertainment. Flowers formed their dress. Their food was flower pollen and their cosmetics were made of flower perfumes.<ref name=":1" />
The depiction of Kinnara in early Indian art is an oft-repeated theme. The ancient sculptures of Sanchi, Barhut, Amaravati, Nagarjunakonda, Mathura, and the paintings of Ajanta depict Kinnaras invariably. Frequently, they are seen in the sculptures flanking the stupas. In this case, they hold garlands or trays containing flowers in their hands for the worship of the Stupas. Sometimes, the Kinnaras appear in the sculptures holding garland in right hand and tray in the left hand. They also appear before Bodhi-Drumas, Dharmacakras, or playing a musical instrument. As such, the portrayal of Kinnaras in early Indian sculpture art is very common.<ref name=":1" />
==Indonesia== [[File:Kalpataru, Kinnara-Kinnari, Apsara-Devata, Pawon Temple.jpg|thumb|Kinnara (male), Kinnari (female), [[Apsara]], and [[Devata]] guarding [[Kalpataru]], the divine tree of life. 8th century [[Pawon]] temple, [[Java]], Indonesia.]] The images of coupled Kinnara and Kinnari can be found in [[Borobudur]], [[Mendut]], [[Pawon]], Sewu, Sari, and [[Prambanan]] temples. Usually, they are depicted as birds with human heads, or humans with lower limbs of birds. The pair of Kinnara and Kinnari usually is depicted guarding [[Kalpataru]], the tree of life, and sometimes guarding a jar of treasure.<ref>{{cite web | title = Pawon | work = National Library of Indonesia, Temples of Indonesia |url = http://candi.pnri.go.id/temples_en/deskripsi-central_java-pawon_38}}</ref> A pair of Kinnara-Kinnari bas-reliefs of Sari temple is unique, depicting Kinnara as celestial humans with birds' wings attached to their backs, very similar to popular image of [[angel]]s.
There are bas-relief in [[Borobudur]] depicting the story of the famous kinnari, [[Manohara]].<ref>{{cite web| title = Borobudur: Golden Tales of the Buddhas | first = John | last = Miksic | publisher = Tuttle Publishing | year = 2012 | isbn = 9781462909100| url = https://books.google.co.id/books?id=jwzQAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA77&lpg=PA77&dq=manohara+story+Borobudur&source=bl&ots=TuZ72i32xf&sig=fAk5WTnwGvkKm7sgcUrMnXBpk5w&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiZv-PW79_VAhWLLY8KHal5Dcc4ChDoAQgpMAE#v=onepage&q=manohara%20story%20Borobudur&f=false}}</ref>
==Thailand== [[File:Kinnari at Phra Meru of HRH Princess Galyani Vadhana.jpg|thumb|left|Sculpture of a ''kinnari'' which was decorated in the royal crematorium of Princess [[Galyani Vadhana]] at [[Sanam Luang]], [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] (2008).]]
The Kinnari, (usually spelt 'Kinnaree' as noted below) ({{lang-th|กินรี}}) in Thai literature originates from India, but was modified to fit in with the Thai way of thinking. The Thai Kinnari is depicted as a young woman wearing an angel-like costume. The lower part of the body is similar to a bird, and should enable her to fly between the human and the mystical worlds. The most popular portrayal of Kinnaree in Thai art probably the golden figures of kinnaree adorned the [[Wat Phra Kaew]] in Bangkok, which describe a half-maiden, half-goose figure.<ref>{{cite book | title = Architecture of Thailand: A Guide to Tradition and Contemporary Forms | author1 = Nithi Sthapitanond | author2 = Brian Mertens | publisher = Editions Didier Millet | year = 2012 | isbn = 9789814260862| url = https://books.google.co.id/books?id=hC5TMZ5QTV0C&pg=PA178&dq=kinnaree+wat+phra+kaew&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwja5fmF_t_VAhXJrY8KHf9pC2sQ6AEILzAC#v=onepage&q=kinnaree%20wat%20phra%20kaew&f=false}}</ref>
The most famous Kinnari in Thailand is the figure known as ''Manora'' (derived from [[Manohara]]), a heroine in one of the stories collected in "Pannas Jataka" a [[Pali]] tome written by a [[Chiangmai]] Buddhist monk and sage around AD 1450–1470.<ref name="Radhakrishnan">{{cite book | title = The Big Book of World Mythology | author = Reeja Radhakrishnan | publisher = Penguin UK | year = 2015 | isbn = 9789352140077| url = https://books.google.co.id/books?id=8tctCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT333&lpg=PT333&dq=Kinnaree+in+Thai+mythology&source=bl&ots=HbqH6WBU0Z&sig=u0B8HJTamKY-8FuVYkOtxgn4eEo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiw16zg_N_VAhVKNI8KHTamDxc4HhDoAQhAMAU#v=onepage&q=Kinnaree%20in%20Thai%20mythology&f=false}}</ref> This is supposed to be a collection of 50 stories of the past lives of the [[Buddha]], known to Buddhists as the [[Jataka]]. The specific tale about Manora the Kinnaree was called Sudhana Jataka, after Prince Sudhana, the [[bodhisattva]] who was also the hero of the story and the husband of Manora.
==Tibet== In Tibet the Kinnara is known as the Miamchi ({{bo|t=མིའམ་ཅི་|w=mi'am ci}}) or 'shang-shang' ({{bo|t=ཤང་ཤང|w=shang shang}}) (Sanskrit: civacivaka). This [[chimera (mythology)|chimera]] is depicted either with just the head or including the whole torso of a human including the arms with the lower body as that of a winged bird. In [[Nyingma]] Mantrayana traditions of [[Mahayoga]] Buddhadharma, the shang-shang symbolizes 'enlightened activity' (Wylie: phrin las). The shang-shang is a celestial musician,<ref>{{cite web | title = Mythical creatures, Kinnara | work = Himalayan Buddhist Art | url = https://himalayanbuddhistart.wordpress.com/tag/kinnara/}}</ref> and is often iconographically depicted with cymbals. A [[homonym]]ic play on words is evident which is a marker of oral lore: the '[[shang]]' ({{bo|t=གཆང|w=gchang}}) is a cymbal or gong like ritual instrument in the indigenous traditions of the Himalaya. The shang-shang is sometimes depicted as the king of the [[Garuda]].
==See also== {{Commons category|Kinnara}} *[[Kalaviṅka]] *[[Kinnara Kingdom]] *[[Centaur]], half-human half-horse creature from [[Greek mythology]] similar to a Kinnara *[[Harpy]], a half-human half-bird mythological creature from the [[Greek mythology]] that resembles the Kinnara *[[Siren (mythology)|Siren]], another mythological creature also from the Greek mythology that resembles the Kinnara and the Harpy *[[Exotic Tribes of Ancient India]]
